turns.content: 4.How long did the Spartan training regimen typically last, and what was involved?

The Spartan training regimen began at the age of 7 and lasted until the age of 30. 

From age 7 to 12, Spartan boys were taken from their families and placed in military-style barracks where they received physical and mental training. They were taught to read, write, and do basic math, but the focus was on developing physical toughness and endurance. They were also taught to be obedient and disciplined, and to always put the needs of the state above their own.

From age 12 to 18, Spartan boys continued their training with intensive physical exercise, including running, jumping, and wrestling. They also received military training, learning how to fight with spears, swords, and shields. At age 18, they were considered full Spartan citizens and were eligible for military service.

From age 18 to 20, Spartan men served in the military as part of the army's basic infantry. From age 20 to 30, they could serve as a hoplite soldier, a more elite and specialized type of infantry that required even more physical fitness and combat training.

Overall, the Spartan training regimen was designed to produce highly skilled and disciplined soldiers who were willing to sacrifice everything for their state.
Wow, that's intense! Did Spartan women receive any similar training?

Unlike Spartan men, Spartan women did not receive military training or participate in physical activities such as running or wrestling. However, Spartan women did receive an education in reading, writing, and music, which was quite unusual for women in ancient Greece.

Additionally, Spartan women enjoyed more freedom and social status than women in other Greek city-states. They were encouraged to exercise and maintain physical fitness, as it was believed that healthy women would produce healthy babies. Spartan women also had greater property rights than women from other city-states, and were able to own land and inherit wealth.

While Spartan women did not receive the same military training as men, they were still trained to be strong, resilient, and independent. It was understood that they had an important role to play in ensuring the success of the Spartan state.

In one famous instance, Spartan women presented their men with shields and told them to "come back with them or on them," meaning that they should return victorious or die trying.

Overall, while Spartan men and women did not fight together on the battlefield, they were both expected to display the same values of courage, discipline, and loyalty to the state.
